content: The folder hierarchy in Thunderbird directly reflects the folder hierarchy in the filesystem within the profile folder. There is no mechanism to make a folder that's not within Local Folders in the filesystem to appear as if it was in the folder pane.
creator: DavidGG

content: Actually, I haven't tried, but a symbolic link might work.
creator: DavidGG

content:
This article explains how to move the location of mail folders:

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Moving_your_mail_storage_location_-_Thunderbird

Basically, you would copy your Local Folders folder from the profile to D, then set the Local Directory to that location.

There's also an add-on to define multiple Local Folders:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/localfolder/
creator: sfhowes

content: Changing the location of the whole Local Folders is not what you want, hence why I didn't suggest that, but it seems that the add-on, which I didn't know existed, would be a way to accomplish what you want, by setting up a separate Local Folders for your Archive, in addition to the Local Folders you already have.
creator: DavidGG

john p said
Sfhowes : Would this not move ALL the folders even the ones where the mail is stored. Problem I have is that I have 6 Mail accts and they have their own folders, When i am done with the mail in those folders I drag and drop the messages to the "Archive" folder I only want the Archive folder to move to D: not all the rest is that possible??

You can move all of Local Folders or mail for specific accounts, since each has a Local Directory (as explained in the kb article). To relocate a specific Local Folder folder, use the add-on.

I've never heard of a single issue re add-on security or privileges, which are described here:

https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/privacy/thunderbird/

content:
There's a hidden setting that controls the resolution at which Thunderbird displays and sometimes has a wrong value for some reason.

Go to Settings > General, click Config Editor at the bottom, then type layout.css.dpi in the search box.

What value does it show? If not -1 (default), note the current value (in case you want to change it back), set it to the default -1, and see whether things look better. If the change makes things worse, just change the setting back to the value it had before.
creator: DavidGG

creator: storyseen

content:
It seems 465 is the only option:

587 (TLS): Recommended for securely sending emails. Requires the use of Transport Layer Security (TLS) encryption. 465 (SSL): Used for SMTP connections encrypted with Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). Note that this port is considered less modern than TLS but is still supported. 25: Typically used for SMTP without encryption (not recommended for secure email sending).
creator: storyseen

content: No, it's only trying to use the username of the deleted account that would cause the problem. “Sending failed. Message couldn’t be sent because the connection to the outgoing server SMTP timed out. Try again.”

If you search for the string "the connection to the outgoing server SMTP timed out" in the top right search field, there will be numerous articles with information about how to resolve this issue.

The most common solution is that Anti-Virus software needs to be switched off from scanning emails.

If the solutions offered don't work, please reply to the post and it will be relisted as in need of a solution.

content:
By any chance are all three using the microsoft office365 server ?

Micosoft now state all email accounts are 'alias' and only the one set up as 'primary account' can send via smtp. You can choose what to set up as 'primary' (done in the webmail microsft account) , but then in Thunderbird you can only use that smtp for all accounts to send - so each account SMTP server settings uses that one SMTP primary account address. So if you do not want replies going to wrong address - set up a 'REply-to' email address in Account Settings'.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you have created a 'Mailing List' in an address book:

In a TO field just insert the Mailing List name itself and all contacts in that Mailing List get email, but do not see anyones email address.

If you for some reason are choosing to not use the actual mailing list name but see all contacts email addresses then put them in a Bcc field.

Another really good alternative is to use an addon called 'Mail Merge' https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/mail-merge/

This can work on .csv file or an address book. So either export the Mailing List as a csv file to a folder on computer OR export the Mailing List itself as LDIF file then import and save as an address book in its own right. OR just create a new address book and put the 'Mailing List contacts into it.

The result is this - email contact is sent a separate email in a TO field, so they only see their name. if you use 'Send Later' option - selected in Mail Merge then all emails get stored in 'Outbox' so you can check before sending.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Reference: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders-potential-complications

Quote: "Occasionally, when a folder is compacted, the mail messages in the folder seem to disappear."

"Thunderbird can not read the index for the file while compacting is in progress, so when you select a folder, the mail in the folder will simply not be displayed until compact completes. When it does complete, the mail will reappear."

creator: markh2

content:
Excel is a Micosoft product using Microsoft code. When you copy/paste into Thunderbird, it's impossible for Thunderbird to have all the necessary code because it is Microsoft specific, so you discover it does not look exactly the same as seen in an Excel document. It looks ok in 'Outlook' because that is owned by Microsoft. Microsoft are not going to let any other software have complete access to all it's code.

If you copy anything even normal text from a Microsoft document it bloats the email with a load of unuseable code. It's also the same if copying anything from a webpage - it copies more than just the text - it copies all the html formatting as well. This can sometimes be an issue when copy pasting images because they may include remote content. So if copying then you need to use 'Edit' > 'Paste without formatting'.

That's why email clients also have the ability to attach files such as the excel file document. This means the recipient can then use Excel on their computer to open and read the document exactly as you intended. Some people do not have Microsoft products installed but use eg: OpenOffice to read those documents. OpenOffice and LibreOffice are pretty good, but are not always a 100% accurate for same reasons - they have to interpret the microsoft code to best ability.

Another alternative as good workaround the issue: If you really need the recipient to see what you have created in Excel but they only need to read it - make the excel document full screen and take a screenshot. Then save it as a jpg image. That image jpeg file can be inserted into an email content inline or attached. REcipient will then see exactly what you see and they will not need any specific software other than any software that displays images.

Hope this info helps you.
creator: Toad-Hall

OK. Let's see if we can figure this without your language being a barrier for me…

I'm going to assume the problem here is that Thunderbird is trying to save sent messages in a Sent folder he cannot create at the expected (default) location for some reason, but that we may fix that by telling it to instead use some other folder that may be available for that on the server.

So change the setting to use another folder, then see whether amongst the available options there is a folder with a name that would indicate it's meant to be used for that, choose it, and see whether that solves the problem.

content:
Hi, you're welcome.

Well, you're gonna have to get familiarised with the terminology in order to be able to troubleshoot this. SMTP refers to the outgoing server. Outgoing servers are all of the same type (SMTP), so there is no need to ask that. POP/IMAP refers to the type of incoming server, which determines how mail for that account is managed by Thunderbird.

Check the following articles, and see whether that allows you to answer the questions I asked in my previous post, or maybe even figure how to solve the problem by yourself:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/difference-between-imap-and-pop3

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/configuration-options-accounts
creator: DavidGG

content: thunderbird opens the profiles.ini file at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to see which profile to open. this is a simple text file and if you're comfortable with minor editing, you can edit the file with the name of the actual profile. it's that easy. If you prefer not to do that, we can give more detail instructions.
creator: davidsk

content: Kijk even of dit artikel u verder helpt: https://support.mozilla.org/nl/kb/instellingen-gegevens-importeren-thunderbird. Het zal dus zaak zijn om de gehele profielmap van de oude laptop te kopiëren en dan op de nieuwe te importeren vanaf USB of harde schijf.
creator: Mozilla-assistent

content: As long as it works, all is good. Here is another way: - exit thunderbird - copy profile to wherever desired - click windows key and 'r' key and press enter - enter thunderbird.exe -p and press enter - you are now in profile manager. click 'create profile', then click next, then enter shortcut name, then click 'choose' and then locate and select the profile and click finish (You can also do these steps after copying profile by clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll down to 'profile folder', click 'about:profiles' and then click the above mentioned 'create profile' button and continue. - when done, you can remove the old profile at appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profile
creator: davidsk

content:
The settings are correct, except use 'normal password' authentication for the incoming and outgoing.

http://help.netzero.net/support/email/tbird.html
creator: sfhowes

content:
Thunderbird has multiple modes of operation that it calls "spaces". You've switched to the Chat space. If you did this by accident, it probably is because you hit the keyboard shortcut associated with that space (Ctrl+5). You may switch back to the Mail space with Ctrl+1.

Alternatively, you may see the spaces available and switch between them with the mouse by using the Spaces Toolbar:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova
creator: DavidGG

content: you will need to provide more information. if you receive mail from others, then the problem is not thunderbird. tell us more.
creator: davidsk

content:
Your mail hasn't disappeared, TB has just lost track of the accounts, probably due to a corrupted prefs file:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1360261
creator: sfhowes

content: you need to provide detail information on what errors you are encountering, plus screenshots of the settings that are involved in the problem.
creator: davidsk

content: When composing a plain text message, wrapping can be set to the window width by changing mailnews.wraplength to 0 (zero) in Settings/General, Config. editor.
creator: sfhowes

content: I went to the General, scrolled to bottom for config editor.. then went in and changed from 72 to 0 and closed and reopened thunderbird.. didn't seem to change anything.. still does not wrap to window..
creator: bobs3

content: Please recheck config editor that it was saved. Also, check addons. If you have any, try help>troubleshoot mode to see if addons are involved.
creator: davidsk

content: thunderbird allows creating archive in local folder. I suggest trying that - and then archiving message there and then checking to see if it is still there from online access. I think that doing those tasks will answer your questions.
creator: davidsk

content: Once Thunderbird was restarted - the dummy account that had a backup of all my mail became blank, none of the local folders are recognized. Essentially there is no backup.
creator: lonejakyl

content: I don't understand… You want Thunderbird to have access to the folders of an IMAP account on the server so you may archive their contents into Local Folders, but don't want to setup any mail account in Thunderbird? Does that make sense to you? How do you expect to be able to tell Thunderbird where to find the messages and remove them from the server even without setting up the mail account in Thunderbird?
creator: DavidGG

content:
I suggest this: - backup profile - update to 91.0.1, exit and backup profile - update to 102.0.1, exit and backup profile - update to 115.0.1, exit and backup profile - if nervous about too many new features, update to 115.14.0 and backup and STOP for now. set updates to MANUAL. - if you want to be current, update to 128.0.1, exit and backup profile - update to current release, 128.6.1, exit, do backup, set updates to MANUAL

Note: by 'backup profile' , these are my suggestions: - exit thunderbird - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to anywhere else
creator: davidsk
